skills.name: Work out the final amount in compound percentage increase problems
Work out the number of time periods in compound percentage increase problems
Work out the total increase in compound percentage decrease problems
Work out the number of time periods in compound percentage decrease problems

explanations.A: Be careful when you are calculating depreciation, the car will reduce in price. We need to use the amount left, 100% - 10% = 90% as the multiplier, and raise this to the power of years.
explanations.B: To find the amount the car depreciates by we find £4500 × 0.9³ and then subtract this from £4500. This gives £1219.50.
explanations.C: It looks like you have used 10% as the multiplier. We need to use the percentage left, 100% - 10% = 90%, as the multiplier, and raise this to the power of years.
explanations.D: Nearly! It looks like you have calculated the new price of the car not the value the car has decreased by.

explanations.A: Nearly! It looks like you have calculated the new price of the car not the value the car has decreased by.
explanations.B: We have £3500 × 0.9⁴ = £2296.35. Subtracting this from £3500 gives £1203.65.
explanations.C: It looks like you have found the value of the car after 5 years. Be careful to find the amount the car depreciates by after 4 years.
explanations.D: It looks like you have found the amount the car depreciates by after 5 years, be careful to find the amount after 4 years.

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you might have rounded up. After 6 years it isn't quite double the value. To help, give the value of the house a number and use a multiplier method to increase its value by 12% every year. How many years will it take for the value to double?
explanations.B: Not quite. To help, give the value of the house a number and use a multiplier method to increase its value by 12% every year. How many years will it take for the value to double?
explanations.C: The best way to answer this question is to keep multiplying 1.12 together in a calculator until we get over 2. We have 1.12⁶ = 1.97 and 1.12⁷ = 2.21, so the answer is 7.
explanations.D: Not quite. To help, give the value of the house a number and use a multiplier method to increase its value by 12% every year. How many years will it take for the value to double?

explanations.A: Not quite. To help, give the value of the house a number and use a multiplier method to increase its value by 15% every year. How many years will it take for the value to double?
explanations.B: The best way to answer this question is to keep multiplying 1.15 together in a calculator until we get over 2. We have 1.15⁴ = 1.75 and 1.15⁵ = 2.01, so the answer is 5.
explanations.C: Not quite. To help, give the value of the house a number and use a multiplier method to increase its value by 15% every year. How many years will it take for the value to double?
explanations.D: Not quite. I think you might have rounded up. After 4 years it isn't quite double the value. To help, give the value of the house a number and use a multiplier method to increase its value by 15% every year. How many years will it take for the value to double?

explanations.A: Remember that the athlete runs 1/10 more each day compared to the day before, not just 1/10 of 2km extra every day.
explanations.B: Remember that the athlete runs 1/10 more each day compared to the day before, not just 1/10 of 2km extra every day. Remember the first day is 2km so that one is already counted.
explanations.C: 1/10 is the same as 10%, so we have 2 × 1.1⁷ = 3.897 km, which rounds to 3.9km.
explanations.D: Remember on the first day they run 2km, so that one is already counted.

explanations.A: Remember on the first day she runs 1km, so that one is already counted.
explanations.B: 1/5 is the same as 20%, so we have 1 × 1.2⁷ = 3.58 km, which rounds to 3.6km.
explanations.C: Remember that the athlete runs 1/5 more each day compared to the day before, not just 1/5 of 1km extra every day. Remember the first day is 1km so that one is already counted.
explanations.D: Remember that the athlete runs 1/5 more each day compared to the day before, not just 1/5 of 1km extra every day.

explanations.A: 1/10 = 10%. 100% - 10% = 90%. Therefore the van is worth 90% of what it was the previous year. Using a multiplier method to calculate its value after 5 years we get: 15000 × 0.9⁵ = £8857.35.
explanations.B: Not quite. Remember the van has lost value by the end of year one. Use a multiplier method to check the number of years.
explanations.C: Be careful. Use a multiplier method to check the number of years.
explanations.D: Be careful. Use a multiplier method to check the number of years.

explanations.A: Not quite. Remember the van has lost value by the end of year one. Use a multiplier method to check the number of years.
explanations.B: Be careful. Use a multiplier method to check the number of years.
explanations.C: 1/10 = 10%. 100% - 10% = 90%. Therefore the van is worth 90% of what it was the previous year. Using a multiplier method to calculate its value after 6 years we get: 12000 × 0.9⁶ = £6377.29.
explanations.D: Be careful. Use a multiplier method to check the number of years.

explanations.A: 100% + 1.5% = 101.5%. As a decimal 101.5% is 1.015. Therefore the multiplier for increasing by 1.5% is 1.015, and the power is 5 for 5 years.
explanations.B: Not quite. Remember the formula should increase £7000 by 1.5%. Multiplying by 0.015 would find 1.5% of 7000, rather than increase by it.
explanations.C: Not quite. Multiplying by 1.15 would be increasing by 15%, rather than 1.5%.
explanations.D: Be careful. 0.15 = 15% NOT 1.5%. Remember when we are increasing by a percentage, we are finding more than 100%. Think of what our multiplier should be if we want to increase by 1.5%.

explanations.A: Be careful. 0.25 = 25% NOT 2.5%. Remember when we are increasing by a percentage, we are finding more than 100%. Think of what our multiplier should be if we want to increase by 2.5%.
explanations.B: Not quite. Remember the formula should increase £7000 by 2.5%. Multiplying by 0.025 would find 2.5% of 7000, rather than increase by it.
explanations.C: Not quite. Multiplying by 1.25 would be increasing by 25%, rather than 2.5%.
explanations.D: 100% + 2.5% = 102.5%. As a decimal 102.5% is 1.025. Therefore the multiplier for increasing by 2.5% is 1.025, and the power is 3 for 3 years.
